TaggedValue.name: description

TaggedValue.name: description
TaggedValue.value: This is an GP practice record entry. There may be 0 to many record entries under a section. Each record entry is made up of a number of elements or data items

TaggedValue.name: description
TaggedValue.value: The name of the person's GP. If the person is registered with a GP practice, their usual GP name will be something volunteered by the person or their representative.

TaggedValue.name: valueSets
TaggedValue.value: Free text

TaggedValue.name: description
TaggedValue.value: Name and address of the person's registered GP practice Registered GP practice details are available from the Person Demographics Service (PDS), or volunteered from the person or their representative. Include details of the practice name and address.

TaggedValue.name: valueSets
TaggedValue.value: Free text

TaggedValue.name: description
TaggedValue.value: The identifier of the registered GP practice.

TaggedValue.name: valueSets
TaggedValue.value: NHS data dictionary : - General medical practice code (patient registration)

TaggedValue.name: description
TaggedValue.value: About me

Model.name: What is most important to me

TaggedValue.name: description
TaggedValue.value: A description of what is most important to you.

TaggedValue.name: description
TaggedValue.value: A description of what is most important to you Emergency Information : - Include any essential information that any professional in health and social care should know about the you in any situation, including emergencies. Other Information : - This could include : - Values, Spirituality/religion, Ethnicity, Culture, Pets, Goals and aspirations, Meaningful activities including leisure activities, visiting places, sport and exercise, listening to music, employment, education, volunteering

TaggedValue.name: valueSets
TaggedValue.value: Free text

Model.name: People who are important to me

TaggedValue.name: description
TaggedValue.value: Details of who is important to you and why.

TaggedValue.name: description
TaggedValue.value: Details of who is important to you and why. They could be family members, carers, friends, members of staff etc. Include how you want the people important to you to be engaged and involved in your care and support in both emergency and normal situations. Include how you stay connected to the people important to you. Who should not be contacted or consulted about your care and support and why, if you wish to say

TaggedValue.name: valueSets
TaggedValue.value: Free text

Model.name: How I communicate and how to communicate with me

TaggedValue.name: description
TaggedValue.value: A description of how you communicate normally.

TaggedValue.name: description
TaggedValue.value: A description of how you communicate normally including any communication aids you use, for example a hearing aid. Include your preferred language of communication, if your first language is not English. Include how you would communicate when you are in pain or distress. Include how you communicate choices. Include how you give feedback or raise a concern. Include how you like to receive information Describe how you would like others to engage and communicate with you, including how you would like to be addressed.

TaggedValue.name: valueSets
TaggedValue.value: Free text

TaggedValue.name: description
TaggedValue.value: A description covering what you are able to do, how you engage with others and how you feel on a typical day through to on a day when you are unwell or really unwell.

TaggedValue.name: description
TaggedValue.value: A description covering what you are able to do, how you engage with others and how you feel on a typical day through to on a day when you are unwell or really unwell Include any causes that might result in you becoming unwell and strategies for avoiding or addressing the causes. For example, not drinking enough water could cause constipation. Include any signs that indicate you might be becoming unwell. On a bad day describe what is different about what you are able to do, how you engage with others and how you feel. Include how your everyday life is affected by any medical conditions e.g. dementia and any symptoms e.g. itchiness, cough, pain and how you manage those conditions. Include past health issues or experiences that need to be considered Include your wellbeing and lifestyle goals and aspirations

TaggedValue.name: valueSets
TaggedValue.value: Free text

TaggedValue.name: description
TaggedValue.value: A description of things you want someone supporting you to do (or not to do).

TaggedValue.name: description
TaggedValue.value: A description of things you want someone supporting you to do (or not to do). Things you want someone to do might include (for example): - Talk to me not to my carer, remind me to take my medication, encourage me to wash my hands regularly, explain to me what is happening and why, respond to my communication. A description of things you do not want someone supporting you to do might include (for example): - Discussing or asking questions about certain topics, making assumptions about something, providing support when it is not wanted, talking to you in a certain way, undergoing a specific intervention or taking a medication the person does not want.

TaggedValue.name: valueSets
TaggedValue.value: Free text

Model.name: How and when to support me

TaggedValue.name: description
TaggedValue.value: A description of how and when you want someone caring for you to support you.

TaggedValue.name: description
TaggedValue.value: A description of how and when you want someone caring for you to support you. This could include support needs in an emergency situation (for example taking blood) This could include support you need to maintain important routines or to carry out particular activities, for example: - Personal care routines, Eating and drinking, Bedtime routines, Taking medications, Moving and transitioning This could also include support needed with:- wearing glasses/hearing aids/false teeth etc, making informed choices or understanding dangers and risks, managing your emotions, moods and behaviours, memory or confusion. Include how your support needs change in different environments. Include any triggers that might result in you needing further support and strategies for avoiding or addressing the triggers. Include how you want the support to be provided.

TaggedValue.name: valueSets
TaggedValue.value: Free text

TaggedValue.name: description
TaggedValue.value: A description of what is also worth knowing about you for people caring or supporting you.

TaggedValue.name: description
TaggedValue.value: A description of what is also worth knowing about you for people caring or supporting you. This could include a short history of your life (where you have worked, where you lived, important events in your life, important people in your past life). This could include a short profile of your current life:- your work / study, your aspirations, your skills, your networks, things you like e.g. particular foods, places, a football team and things you like to talk about, things you dislike This could also include any care and support preferences that have not been included elsewhere.

TaggedValue.name: valueSets
TaggedValue.value: Free text

TaggedValue.name: description
TaggedValue.value: This is a record of the date that this information was last updated.

TaggedValue.name: valueSets
TaggedValue.value: Date and Time

TaggedValue.name: description
TaggedValue.value: Where relevant, this is a record of name, relationship/role and contact details of the individual who supported the person to write this section e.g. carer, family member, advocate, professional.

TaggedValue.name: valueSets
TaggedValue.value: Free text

TaggedValue.name: description
TaggedValue.value: The link to the person's multimedia file

TaggedValue.name: valueSets
TaggedValue.value: Link to URL

TaggedValue.name: valueSets
TaggedValue.value: FHIR value set : - SDSjobrole

TaggedValue.name: description

TaggedValue.name: description
TaggedValue.value: Any supplementary or personalised information that relates to the person's needs, concerns and problems.

TaggedValue.name: valueSets
TaggedValue.value: Free text

TaggedValue.name: description
TaggedValue.value: The overall goals, hopes, aims or targets that the person has. Including anything that the person wants to achieve that relates to their future health and wellbeing. Each goal may include a description of why it is important to the person. Goals may also be ranked in order of importance or priority to the person.

TaggedValue.name: description
TaggedValue.value: The coded value associated with the person's goals, aim's and hopes. e.g. 999002111000000103 |Occupational therapy goals simple reference set (foundation metadata concept)|

TaggedValue.name: valueSets
TaggedValue.value: SNOMED CT : - 413350009|Finding with explicit context|: 246090004|Associated finding|=300798006 |Able to participate in sporting activities (finding)|, 408729009|Finding context|=410518001|Goal|

TaggedValue.value: Any supplementary and personalised information relating to the person's goals, aims and hopes.

TaggedValue.value: Free text

TaggedValue.name: description
TaggedValue.value: Assessment of the person's motivations to achieve this goal, how important the goal is to the person on a scale of 1-10.

TaggedValue.name: valueSets
TaggedValue.value: Numeric scale 1 - 10

TaggedValue.name: description
TaggedValue.value: Actions or activities the person or others plan to take to achieve the person's goals and the resources required to do this.

Model.name: Agreed with person or legitimate representative

TaggedValue.name: description

TaggedValue.name: description
TaggedValue.value: These are the things to do and people to contact, should an individual’s health or other circumstances get worse for safety.

TaggedValue.name: description
TaggedValue.value: Signs to watch out for that may indicate a significant change in health or other circumstances e.g. feeling agitated

TaggedValue.name: description
TaggedValue.value: Guidance on specific actions or interventions that may be required or should be avoided in specific situations. This may include circumstances where action needs to be taken if a carer is unable to care for the person. A statement of suggested actions. Usually expressed as: in the event of X do Y.

TaggedValue.name: description
TaggedValue.value: The coded value for what should happen

TaggedValue.name: valueSets
TaggedValue.value: SNOMED CT : - << 71388002 |Procedure| OR << 129125009 |Procedure with explicit context|

TaggedValue.name: description
TaggedValue.value: Any supplementary or personalised information regarding what should happen

TaggedValue.name: valueSets
TaggedValue.value: Free text

TaggedValue.name: description

TaggedValue.name: description
TaggedValue.value: Details of coping strategies used

TaggedValue.name: description
TaggedValue.value: The coping strategies are defined as thoughts and behaviours that people use to manage the internal and external demands of situations that are appraised as stressful. This should also include a record of any tools used to carry out the coping strategy.

TaggedValue.name: valueSets
TaggedValue.value: Free text

TaggedValue.name: description
TaggedValue.value: The date when the coping strategy started

TaggedValue.name: description
TaggedValue.value: The date when the coping strategy ended

TaggedValue.name: valueSets

TaggedValue.name: description
TaggedValue.value: This is the content of any additional care and support plan which the person and/or care professional consider should be shared with others providing care and support. May be structured in different ways, e.g. tables, diagrams, images. This is the content of any additional care and support plan which the individual and/or care professional consider should be shared with others providing care and support. It should be structured as recommended for the care and support plan and if contains additional detail, it may be referenced here.
